messageBody:
I was originally running Ant from the commandline to startup JUnit,
but then switched to simply running JUnit, when it didn't work with
Ant. That's when I found the problem, namely, if I don't put the
source files into the same directory as the class files, it doesn't
work. I was using the GUI testrunner for this, but was never quite
sure what I was loading, so tried the Text textrunner, and now it
appears that I have CLASSPATH problems (the old
NoClassDefFoundError). Thanks!
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> JUnit does not depend on source files. You are probably using Ant
or
> some other tool to start up JUnit. The problem is most likely
there.
> Try it straight from the command line and see if you get different
> results.
>
> =jason
>
> On Wed, 2003-05-14 at 19:54, junitguy wrote:
> > I keep my source files in a "src" directory. When I build with
Ant,
> > I compile my class files into a "build" directory. I would like
to
> > then run JUnit tests against the newly created classes in the
build
> > directory, but JUnit can't seem to do this unless the .java files
are
> > copied there as well. I've tried setting a classpath to both
> > locations, but this does not solve the problem. Someone have a
good
> > solution to this problem?
